chapter.title: Overview of Globus Toolkit Documentation
chapter.para: This document includes the policies and guidelines behind the documentation for GT distributions, requirements for documents and help for using the DocBook XML Schema for common documentation elements.

Our goal is to provide comprehensive documentation in a clear concise manner and in language that is not too technical or obscure. To that end, we encourage all feedback, suggestions and comments for improving our documentation and finding ways to make the information more easily understandable. For broken links and other simple technical issues with using the docs online, send an email to webmaster@globus.org.
For everything else, you can file a bug in Bugzilla (use the Documentation project) or use the docfeedback box available on each page of documentation online.
We thank you ahead of time for your help!

chapter.title: Why DocBook?
chapter.para: All Globus Toolkit documentation will be marked up to conform to the DocBook XML DTD. Theoretically, any strict DTD would have been sufficient. However, DocBook is a publishing standard based on XML with similar goals to the Globus Toolkit Documentation project. Some specific reasons why we are using DocBook:

listitem.para: It is open-source.
A growing community surrounds DocBook (has mailing lists).
A number of free and commercial tools are available for editing and publishing DocBook documents.
It enables us to publish in a variety of formats (HTML, PDF, etc.)
XML separates content from presentation: It relieves each contributor of the burden of presentation, freeing each writer to focus on content and sharing knowledge.
It is well tested technology. (It has been in development since the early 1990's).

chapter.para: The following DocBook primer walks you through the basics, and should cover the needs for 95 percent of the documentation we produce. Remember to:

listitem.para: Always close your tags with corresponding end-tags and to not use other tag minimization.
Write all elements and attributes in lowercase.
Quote all attributes.

chapter.title: Setting Up DocBook
chapter.para: There are many ways to work with the DocBook documentation. At its simplest, you need CVS access, then if you know how the code works, you can edit the XML files in a text editor. However, many people are more comfortable setting up a separate test environment. You'll need some things to duplicate the processing that occurs when producing the HTML/PDF output.
The following can help you with the Globus Toolkit Docbook XML documentation:

listitem.para: Docbook XML DTD version 4.4 - The document type definition for XML. You can find an RPM or DEB package or you can download a zip file from the site linked from here.
XSL Stylesheets version 1.69.1 (docbook-xsl) - The stylesheets to convert to HTML. We have been using a stylesheet based upon NWalsh's "chunk.xsl".

xsltproc - The processor that will take an XML document and, given a xsl stylesheet, convert it to HTML. It needs libxml2 and libxslt (available in RPM and DEB formats or from xmlsoft.org). It comes with xmllint, which will be very useful for debugging.
Some editing tool. Some options are:

listitem.simpara: XMLMind Personal Edition This is a highly recommended WYSIWYG XML editor that works well with DocBook. The Personal Edition is free and provides an excellent way to 'visualize' your docs before committing your changes. It validates and shows xincluded frags (discussed below). For more information about using XMLMind, read this article (to read about editing xincluded files in particular, read this page of the article).
Oxygen XML Editor (there is also a plugin available for Eclipse)
For a comprehensive list of editing tools, click here

chapter.para: Once it has been determined that your project will be included in the next GT release, then you will need to contact the Documentation Coordinator. The Documentation Coordinator will also assist you with conversion to DocBook as time permits.

chapter.title: Creating New Docs
chapter.para: For the most part, you only need to edit existing DocBook files. However, the following information is helpful if you need to create a new standalone doc.

note.simpara: We only encourage standalone docs to supplement information that is already in the templates for standard documentation or for information that does not fit within the template's structure. If you're not sure, contact the Documentation Coordinator.

section.title: Writing New Docs
section.para: First, you need to define a title for your document. Try to use a title that is as informative as possible using the fewest amount of words possible. Also, try to compose a title with certain 'keywords' that will catch the attention of readers who are looking for this information.

Then start thinking about the possible sections and subsections you will have in your document. Make sure you coordinate with the Documentation Coordinator to make sure you're not writing something that someone else has already written.

section.title: Adding New Docs to Your Release Manuals
section.para: Make sure your XML file is properly named - you should use the project name that prepends other files in your directory (for example GridFTP) and then one or two words describing the contents.

listitem.para: Make sure the new file is added to CVS in your project's directory.
Email Documentation Coordinator with details about where you think this doc fits into Admin, Dev, User Guide. If necessary, we can create a standalone guide.

section.para: Look at the existing files in your project (or checkout another project and look at their code) to see how the code is used in practice.

chapter.title: Globus Toolkit Documentation Strategy
chapter.para: Starting with GT 4.0, we use templates of the minimum required topics for each project. During the development process, more and more information is added and refined with each release. This process is facilitated by the Documentation Coordinator and Release Manager. With each development release, the documentation becomes more and more complete. This iterative process allows the documentation to be built up over time instead of in a rush right before final release. When development for the next major version begins, we copy the existing documentation to a docs/development/[version]-drafts/ directory and then the Project Chairs build on those docs.

section.title: Fragments
section.para: To reduce duplication and make sure we have a single source for all information, we also utilize 'fragments' of frequently used information. For example, a brief overview of the project is stored in [project_name]_Overview_Brief_Frag.xml and embedded wherever such a description is needed. Thus, any update to the Overview fragment is updated in each place it has been embedded and remains standard throughout the documentation. As you can guess from this example, such frags have the following naming convention: [project_name]_[description]_Frag.xml

section.title: Standard organization
section.para: Our templates provide a standard organization for all system administrator, user and developer guides for all projects of the Globus Toolkit. If a section does not apply for a project, there will be a statement to the effect: "This section does not apply for this project." For example, if a project does not have a GUI interface, then the [project]_Interface_GUI_Frag.xml file should explicitly say so. In some guides, the Documentation Coordinator will comment out frags that do not apply (for example, very few components have a GUI, therefore, it is confusing/misleading to consistently list GUI topics where there is no applicable information.

From time to time, there will be information that is not compatible with the standard organization. In these cases, if you have a clear idea of where it should go and how to add it, go ahead and update it. If you're not sure how to include the information, consult the Documentation Coordinator. For more information, see Creating New Docs.

section.title: Release cycle for documentation
section.para: The following list outlines what happens with documentation in a typical GT release cycle:

listitem.para: Once development begins for the next major release (we'll use 5.0.0 as an example release), a new folder is added to the development docs directory as follows: toolkit/docs/5.0/5.0.0/.
Documentation Coordinator updates files for the upcoming release (changes version numbers, etc.)
Developers start updating documents in this development directory for the upcoming release.
For each development release leading up to the stable release:
After source code freeze, a corresponding directory is added to the development docs directory - for example, ../toolkit/docs/development/4.1.5.
The drafts directory is frozen and copied over to the new directory.
Documentation Coordinator updates references to release numbers.
Documentation Coordinator and Release Manager go over development documentation for any other necessary revisions.
Release notes are completed and the development release is announced.
Freeze is lifted for drafts directory.
Before final stable release:
A new directory is added to the docs directory - for example, .../toolkit/docs/5.0/5.0.0.
After source code freeze, the drafts directory is frozen and copied over to the new directory.
Documentation Coordinator updates references to release numbers.
Documentation Coordinator and Release Manager go over development documentation for any other necessary revisions.
Release notes are completed and the final release is announced.
After final stable release, the drafts directory is removed.

Starting with 4.2.0, we are releasing a new documentation directory with each incremental release. For example, before releasing 4.2.1, we had a docs freeze, copied existing information to toolkit/docs/4.2.1/, unfroze, and then updated documentation and release notes in the new directory.

chapter.title: Structure of a Component's Release Manuals
chapter.para: Each book under a project has its own subdirectory. The default list of subdirectories is now:

listitem.para: admin (Admin Guide)
developer (Developer's Guide)
mig (Migrating Guide)
pi (Public Interfaces Guide)
qp (Quality Profile)
rn (Release Notes)
user (User's Guide)

chapter.para: Each technology family shares one Key Concepts Guide available in the key directory of the family directory. For example, the Key Concepts Guide for GRAM5 is located in this directory: toolkit/docs/5.0/5.0.0/execution/key/.
The main xml file for each book is the index.xml file.

note.para: This list of books may be customized per project. For example, if the project has no end-users, there should not be a "User's Guide".

chapter.para: Each book is divided into chapters (within the <chapter> element) and each chapter is output as a single web page (this also applies to <reference>, <appendix>, and <article> elements). Many of these pages include fragments (which are separate XML files as described here).
Take a look at the files of existing DocBook documents, or see the following chapter to get an idea of how they are tied together.

listitem.para: Clarity in presentation.
Use best practices learned from the print world, web, and other media, about use of grammar, space, writing style, etc:

Consistency. It's important to be consistent in the use of terms and names for your project. For example, make sure that when you name a project, you consistently use the same name throughout documentation to avoid confusion.

Use standardized language. Consider international readers by not using slang or colloquial terms - many of your readers use English as a second language. This also helps make translation easier for anyone interested in translating the documentation for internationalization efforts.
All jargon used in documentation needs to be defined (using the glossary feature). Use standardized terms when available, avoiding implicit understanding of specific Globus Toolkit terms.

Single source - This practice significantly reduces obsolescence in writing and the burden of maintaining up-to-date documentation:
Show where to find information instead of duplicating information - use a link or include text from a Frag or a subset from a bigger doc using XIncludes - anywhere in the version release manuals.
If the information is not found elsewhere, then create one place for it where others can refer to it (see Creating New Docs or contact the Documentation Coordinator if you need help).
Consider Globus Toolkit documentation as a set of books. Each book contains chapters and sections, where each chapter is a web page.

section.title: Key Concepts
section.para: Key Concepts guides are at the 'family' level (common/, data/, execution/, info/, and security/) and explain important concepts about the technologies within that family.
There is a very basic outline for key concepts but they should be customized for the specific technology they're describing.
We encourage the use of graphics to demonstrate your key concepts!
As necessary, we also encourage adding standalone files if you have a large amount of information you want to break down into separate files.

TODO: add guidelines for writing key concepts: heavy use of graphics, should describe each component in the family (for example, security does a great job of describing cryptology and such, but does not mention how the underlying components are related).
The Key Concepts Guide has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Overview: Provides high-level overview of the features of the component, as well as a description of the problem space of relevance to the component. The discussion should be aimed at readers who are non-experts.
Conceptual Details: The bulk of this guide, includes several paragraphs outlining the fundamental concepts that underly the component.
Related Documents: Link to other documents (internal or external, whitepapers, presentations, etc.) that supplement the Overview.

section.title: User's Guides
section.para: This guide is for the most challenging audience for our documentation: end users. Please always keep in mind that end users may have little technical background/knowledge for your project.
There are certain components (such as C Common Libraries, the Aggregator Framework) that do not have end-users and therefore do not have User's Guides.
The User's Guide has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Introduction: Introduces the project to end users and references to the (upcoming) Toolkit-level User's Guide where they can find general end user-oriented information. Should mention all common end-user issues. For example, the introduction to the Message-level Security User's Guide mentions "The main user issues for this component deal with configuring credential-related settings. There are multiple mechanisms for doing this:..." and goes on to briefly list them.
Using [component]: describes the most common ways end-users interact with this component using examples.
Command-line tools: Includes the ...Interface_Commandline_Frag.xml, which gives details on all commands.
Graphical user interface: Includes the ...Interface_Commandline_Frag.xml, which describes how the UI works including browser/interface strengths and limitations.
Troubleshooting: Describes user-friendly help on common problems they may encounter.

section.title: System Administrators Guides
section.para: The System Administrators Guide at the project-level picks up where the top-level Installation Guide leaves off and has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Introduction: Introduces the guide to sysadmins and points them to the top-level Installation Guide for comprehensive basic installation/configuration info. Mentions common admin-specific issues.
Building and installing: Includes information about building and installing your project that is not covered in the top-level Installation Guide.
Configuring: Includes the [project]_Interface_Configuring_Frag.xml fragment for full information on configuration settings [cris: should we also embed environmental variables frag?].

Deploying: Includes deploying information (into various containers/environments) for your project that is not covered in the top-level Installation Guide. [fixme: include java ws core deploying frags?]
Testing: Includes procedures for how to test the configuration that is not covered in the top-level Installation Guide. Must include examples of the tests.
Security Considerations: Embeds the Security Considerations frag .
Troubleshooting: Describes help for common problems sysadmins may experience.

section.title: Developer's Guides
section.para: Keep in mind the following when you edit Developer's Guides:

listitem.para: This documentation should be written for ongoing reference by developers.
List practical development and diagnostics tools and methodologies.
List and link to Globus Toolkit development resources, API docs, schema files, etc.. Remember you can use ViewCVS to link to the latest versions of schema, WSDL, and other files.

section.para: The Developer's Guide has the following required topics:

listitem.para: Introduction: Introduces the project to developers (people who use the programmatic public interfaces of GT). Mentions the main developer-specific issues that this guide will address.

Before you begin: Collects information useful to developers before they start working with the technology. Includes the following fragments: Features Summary, Tested Platforms, Backward Compatibility, Tech Dependencies, Associated Standards, and Security Consideration.
Usage scenarios: Describes different scenarios of developing with this component (should describe using the programmatic interfaces and provide examples).

Tutorials: Include tutorials. Can link to any developer tutorials. Tutorials do not conform to a template, but they are strongly encouraged. The files can be in any format as long as they are available online. You can add the files to your project's doc CVS repository or on your own web space. Keep in mind the following when writing them:
Use links to Developers Guide or use xincludes instead of duplicating information.
List suggestions for installing and setting up a development environment; these can be annotated links to the top-level Installation Guide.
Provide working examples.
Include general rules to follow for stability, scalability.
Include a summary of important links used by developers.
Note any deprecated tools and methods by linking to prior versions instead of describing them in current docs.
If there are no tutorials, write "There are no tutorials available at this time."
Architecture and design overview: Describes the architecture and design at a high-level with links to architecture and design docs. Diagrams are strongly encouraged.
API: Includes API Frag which links to API docs.
Commandline tools: Includes Commandline Frag which details all commandline clients.
Configuration: Includes Config Frag which details all configuration settings.
Domain-specific interface (name it): Includes Domain Frag which describes any domain-specific interfaces (such as the job descriptions for GRAM5).
Environmental Variables: Includes Environment Variables Frag which describes any project-specific environmental variables.
GUI: Includes GUI Frag which describes any GUI interfaces.
Services and WSDL: Includes WSDL Frag which describes WSRF interfaces including schemas and WSDL (for WS components only).
Debugging: Provides information for debugging the project.
Troubleshooting: Describes help for common problems developers may experience.
Samples: If available, includes ..._Samples.xml which includes sample code for your project.
Related Documentation: Links to PDFs and whitepapers about protocols, etc., about the project.

section.title: Public Interfaces Guides
section.para: A sub-set of the Developer's Guide, identifies the public interfaces for the project and includes the following topics:

listitem.para: APIs (includes the API frag)
Services and WSDL (includes the WSDL frag)
Command-line tools (includes the Commandline frag)
Graphical User Interface (includes the GUI frag)
Domain-specific interface (includes the Domain frag)
Configuration interface (includes to the Config frag)
Environment variable interface (includes the Environment Variables frag)

section.title: Release Notes
section.para: Describes implementation details to existing and potential users of a project distributed as part of a new stable release.
Release notes include the following topics:

listitem.para: Component Overview (includes the Overview frag)
Feature Summary (includes the Features frag)
Changes Summary (includes the Change Summary frag)
Bug Fixes (includes the Fixed Bugs frag)
Known Problems (includes the Known Problems frag)
Technology Dependencies (includes the Dependencies frag)
Tested Platforms (includes the Platform Summary frag)
Backward Compatibility Summary (includes the Compatibility frag)
Associated Standards (includes the Standards frag)

section.title: Quality Profiles
section.para: Presents any current reports available on test coverage, resource and memory leak analysis, bounds checking, and performance profiles.
Quality Profiles include the following required topics.

listitem.para: Outstanding bugs (includes the Known Bugs frag)
Bug Fixes (includes the Fixed Bugs frag)

section.title: Migrating Guides

listitem.para: Migrating from GT2 (includes the Migrating GT2 frag)
Migrating from GT3 (includes the Migrating GT3 frag)

section.title: Samples
section.para: Samples do not conform to a template; however, they are strongly encouraged. Samples provide test code for a project, which makes it far easier to start developing with a project. Include your code in a [project]_Samples.xml file and notify the Doc Coordinator (who will include it in the top-level Samples guide and your project's Developer Guide).

section.title: Replaceable Text

important.para: The following replaces text entities. This change was made in order to be more compatible with XMLMind Personal Edition.

section.para: Replaceable text maps a 'nickname' to a string of text. We use them to refer to version numbers that will be automatically updated from one place instead of having to manually update for each release.
To do this, we use the <replaceable> element with the role attribute set to entity:

For example:
<replaceable role="entity">version</replaceable>

listitem.para: <replaceable role="entity">version</replaceable> - Maps to the current 3-digit version number (for example, version).
<replaceable role="entity">shortversion</replaceable> - Maps to the current 2-digit version number (for example, shortversion).
<replaceable role="entity">previousversion</replaceable> - Maps to the previous 2-digit version number (for example, previousversion).

important.para: The <replaceable> cannot be used in attributes - in other words, you cannot use this in a URL in a link. The doc coordinator is currently working on another way to replace text in attributes.

chapter.title: Paragraphs (<para> and <simpara>)
chapter.para: Not surprisingly, the paragraph tag, <para>, is the most used tag in our documentation. Not only can you use it to separate your text into separate paragraphs, it may also contain block level structures (lists, figures, and so on).

But there is another, similar tag that is also used - <simpara>. This tag also separates content into separate paragraphs, however, it is more restrictive in that it can only contains text characters.
The main difference between them is there is more space between <para> tags than <simpara> tags.

important.para:
You also need <para> or <simpara> tags around text in the following elements: <listitem> , <important>
<note> , <tip> , and <warning> .

section.title: Brackets
section.para: Brackets (< and >) used within the flow of text (ie, within <para> or <simpara> elements) must be represented in code as follows: the opening bracket is represented as < (short for "less than") and the closing bracket is represented as > (short for "greater than".

chapter.title: Headings and Sections
chapter.para: Headings are automatically created from <title> elements directory following these DocBook elements:

listitem.para: <refentry> (in Commandline Frag)
<section> (Sections nest recursively to make subsections - each section will correspond to a heading level in the HTML/PDF output.)

chapter.para: Each of the abovementioned elements should also have the id attribute and be followed by a <title> tag.

section.title: id attribute
section.para: The id attribute is standard and can be used with all elements. It comes in very handy when linking between documents (more about this when talking about links). The value of id must be unique throughout a book.
When it comes to creating unique ids for your <section>s, please use the following naming convention:
section.screen: [name of your project folder]-[short name for doc]-[short term related to this section]
section.para: For example, this would be a unique id for the "Introduction" section of the GridFTP System Administrator's Guide: gridftp-admin-intro

section.title: <title> tag
section.para: The opening <section> tag is followed by the <title> tag. The value of the <title> tag is used as the link text for olinks.
For example, the value of the <title> tag for this section is "Headings and Sections", which is the heading above. The level of the heading (h1, h2, etc) depends on how deeply the section is nested.

chapter.title: Documenting Code (<computeroutput> and <filename>)
chapter.para: For displaying a snippet of code, a filename or anything else you just want to appear as a part of a sentence, we normally use the <computeroutput> or <filename> elements. They take the place of the <code> or <tt> HTML tags.
For bigger chunks of code, use the <screen> tag. Just wrap your code block in it, mono-spacing with indents, and DocBook takes care of it automatically.

section.title: External Linking (<ulink>)

The output will create a hyper-link to Oracle in the HTML-version of the documentation: Oracle Corporation.

important.simpara: Do NOT use ampersands in your hyper links. These are reserved for referencing entities; instead, use the following code for ampersand: & .

chapter.title: Graphics (<figure>)

note.simpara: Currently this section only takes HTML output into consideration - not a PDF version.

chapter.para:
To insert a graphic we use the <figure>, <mediaobject>, and <imageobject> elements.
You should also provide a brief description wrapped in <textobject> - in HTML this will be the ALT text. If you want a caption to appear below the graphic, use the <caption> element with a <para> tag.

note.para: The path to the graphic should be relative to the XML file you are editing.

chapter.para: The HTML output looks like this:

textobject.phrase: This is an image of the flow in WebMDS

caption.para: This is an image of the flow in WebMDS

chapter.para: In addition to using the above code, do the following:

listitem.para: In general, put your graphics in the same directory as the document.
Keep the width of the graphic no greater than 700px (500px is best).

chapter.title: Lists
chapter.para: In general, making a list in DocBook is similar to doing the same thing in HTML - except in DocBook, <li> becomes <listitem> and the text in each <listitem> must be wrapped in in either a <para> or <simpara> element.
The following sections describe how to make the DocBook equivalent of the three usual HTML lists: unordered lists, ordered lists and definition lists.

section.title: How to make an unordered list (<itemizedlist>)
section.para: The HTML/PDF output looks like this:

section.title: How to make a definition list (<variablelist>)
section.para: This kind of list is called a "variable list" in DocBook and is a little more complex than the previous lists. These are the tags you'll need to make it happen: <variablelist>, <varlistentry>, <term> and <listitem>:
section.screen: <variablelist> <varlistentry> <term>Definition term goes here</term> <listitem> <para>And definition/description goes here</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> <varlistentry> <term>Another term goes here</term> <listitem> <para>And more stuff goes here</para> </listitem> </varlistentry> </variablelist>
section.para: The HTML/PDF output looks like this:

listitem.para: And definition/description goes here
And more stuff goes here

section.para: Remember, each <listitem> must be wrapped in in either a <para> or <simpara> element.

chapter.title: Italics and Bold (<emphasis>)
chapter.para: Our documentation uses two flavors of emphasis - italics and bold type. DocBook uses one - <emphasis>.
The <emphasis> tag defaults to italics when parsed. If you want to emphasize with bold type, use <emphasis role="strong">.

para.emphasis: This little sentence uses just the <emphasis> tag.
This little sentence uses the <emphasis role="strong"> tag.

chapter.para: DocBook provides a few elements that can be very useful for calling attention to certain information by setting them off from the text: <caution> , <important> , <tip> , and <warning> .

chapter.title: Glossary
chapter.para: The glossary for each version's release manuals is found online at [path to doc version]/glossary.html For example, you can find this version's glossary page here: glossary.html.
Every project should make sure that any jargon or special terms appear in this list. To do so you need to add some markup in two places:

listitem.para: glossary.xml - Located in the root folder of the documentation (for example, docs/5.0/5.0.0/glossary.xml) This file acts as the centralized glossary database. Terms are added in <glossdiv> tags that correspond to the appropriate letter of the alphabet. For example, if you wanted to add the term "proxy certificate", you would open glossary.xml, look for the <glossdiv>P</glossdiv> section and add the following markup in alpha order with the other terms:
listitem.screen: <glossentry id="proxy-cert"> <glossterm>proxy certificate</glossterm> <glossdef> <para> A short lived certificate issued using a EEC. A proxy certificate typically has the same effective subject as the EEC that issued it and can thus be used in its place. GSI uses proxy certificates for single sign on and delegation of rights to other entities.</para> </glossdef> </glossentry>

listitem.para: Next, within your project's documentation, add the <glossterm> tag to each instance you want that term linked to the glossary:

important.simpara: If the term in your documentation varies at all from the value of <glossterm> in glossary.xml, you'll need to add a baseform attribute that matches the value:

listitem.para:
Glossaries are added at the end of each book containing one or more glossary terms. When you commit changes, if you see errors such as: Warning: glossary.collection specified, but there are 0 automatic glossariesthen an automatic glossary needs to be added to that book. Simply add the following right before the ending book tag (</book>):
<glossary role="auto" id="glossary-gridftpDeveloper"> <glossdiv> <title>A</title> <glossentry> <glossterm>Dummy term</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>This is a dummy entry for the automatic glossary database. Do not edit.</para> </glossdef> </glossentry> </glossdiv> </glossary>
The only thing you should update above is the id attribute. DocBook will handle the rest.

chapter.para: When using an automatic glossary database, there are problems with using the available <glosssee> (See) and <glossseealso> (See also) tags. Instead, if you want to refer to another glossary term within the database, add something like this (using <ulink>):
where the text after the pound sign (#) is equal to the id attribute in the <glossentry> tag in glossary.xml.

chapter.title: Indexing

note.para: The Documentation Coordinator will be sending emails to gtmanuals-dev@globus.org on this subject.

chapter.para: You should mark up words in your documents that you would like to see show up in an index (which appears at the end of a project's table of contents). We are working on using specialized indexes to consolidate certain information (such as "how tos").
Use <indexterm> , <primary> and <secondary> for this. See these links for an explanation.
